## Stress and the brain

![@mcewen_physiology_2007 Figure 1](../include/img/mcewen-2007-f1.jpg)

## Homeostasis

- == maintenance of stable internal environment
- e,g., Regulation of physiological variables (e.g., blood $O_2$) via negative feedback [@Cannon1929-ij]
- But do animals really require stable internal environments or *adaptive* ones?
  
## Allostasis

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width=50%}
- @Sterling1988-rl
- Adaptation to *changing* external conditions
- Regulation is active process
- Regulation is anticipatory, varies by circumstance
- Targets vary [@Ramsay2014-la]
:::
::: {.column width=50%}
![https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paula_Radcliffe](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Paula_Radcliffe_NYC_Marathon_2008_cropped.jpg/500px-Paula_Radcliffe_NYC_Marathon_2008_cropped.jpg){width="50%"}
:::
::::

## Stress and the brain

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width=50%}
- **Acute** stress
    + Short duration
    + Fast action required
    + HPA (Cortisol), SAM (NE/Epi) axes
    - Brain detects threat
    - Mobilizes physiological, behavioral responses
:::
::: {.column width=50%}
- vs. **Chronic** stress
    + Long duration, persistent
:::
::::

## Glucocorticoid release



:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width=50%}
- Adrenal cortex releases cortisol
  - Increases blood glucose levels
  - Suppresses immune system
  - Reduces inflammation
  - Aids in metabolism
+ Receptors in brain and body
:::
::: {.column width=50%}
![@Wikipedia-contributors2025-sy](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/HPA_Axis_Diagram_%28Brian_M_Sweis_2012%29.svg/700px-HPA_Axis_Diagram_%28Brian_M_Sweis_2012%29.svg.png)
:::
::::

## Glucocorticoids

![http://www.molecularbrain.com/content/figures/1756-6606-3-2-1-l.jpg](../include/img/cortisol-molecular-brain.jpg)

## Glucocorticoid cascade hypothesis

- Cortisol receptors in hippocampus, amygdala, hypothalamus
    - Hippocampus regulates HPA axis via hypothalamus
- Prolonged cortisol exposure reduces hippocampus response
    - Reduces volume, connectivity in hippocampus
- Hippocampus critical for long-term memory formation
    - Chronic stress impairs long-term memory

## Glucocorticoid cascade hypothesis

- But, cortisol -> stress link not straightforward 

```{r, out.width="100%", fig.cap="[@faresjo_higher_2013](http://dx.doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0073828)"}
knitr::include_graphics("../include/img/faresjo-2013.jpg")
```

## Glucocorticoid cascade hypothesis

- @Sapolsky2016-hs
  - Some non-human animals demonstrate sensitivity to conspecifics' distress
  - Pain thresholds lower (sensitivity greater) when a mouse's cage mate is also in pain
  - Rats will cooperate to release distressed cage mate, foregoing food rewards

---

![](../include/img/zebras-sapolsky.jpg)

- Zebras don't "worry" about predation by lions

## Glucocorticoid cascade hypothesis

- Phasic (short-term) vs. chronic (long-term)
- *Physical* stress (hunger, thirst, injury, disease) vs. *psychological/social* stress

# Wrap up

## Main points

- Fear responses include behavior, physiology, internal states
- Parallels between human and non-human animal responses support
- Like happiness and pleasure, fear engages network of brain systems
- Amygdala important node in this network, but not exclusive

## Main points

- Stressors arise from multiple sources
- Acute (short-term) vs. chronic (long-term) stress distinction crucial
- Corticosteroid receptors found across the CNS
- Some animals experience others' distress as stressful
